Title: Beethoven: Symphony #5 - Rare 1961 George Szell, CSO
Description:
From a rare WGN broadcast of 1961, George Szell leads the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in Beethoven's Symphony #5. This video should prove revealing because it clearly shows Szell's handling of the legendary tricky opening of the first movement (with repeat).

II:  8:03 https://youtu.be/fnDCYGab8u0?t=482
III: 18:03 https://youtu.be/fnDCYGab8u0?t=1083
IV: 23:44 https://youtu.be/fnDCYGab8u0?t=1424

Git You One!: https://www.amazon.com/Chicago-Symphony-Orchestra-Telecasts-Mussorgsky/dp/B00006LPGT/ref=sr_1_5?crid=2IXGP2TNAVL93&keywords=chicago+symphony+orchestra+historic+telecasts&qid=1691874197&sprefix=chicago+symphony+orchestra+historic+telecasts%2Caps%2C132&sr=8-5

This is followed by Gulda performing Bach's Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue in recital (1964)

Title: George Szell/NY Philharmonic: Schubert’s Unfinished Symphony 1947
Description:
George Szell conducts the NY Philharmonic in performance of Schubert’s Symphony in B minor, D.759, aka Unfinished Symphony on December 21st, 1947. Broadcast by CBS, simulcast to WCCO Minnesota where Reynolds Marchant recorded it on tape. 

I wish the quality of this recording was better - but given I cannot find this performance anywhere on the internet I figured it would be worth sharing anyway. I did some work trying to reduce the impact of the distorted parts with mixed results. 

This is by far the earliest NY Philharmonic radio broadcast I’ve come across in the archive - a clue is the paper-backed 3M tape - something that was only produced in 1947 (with the black oxide). You can tell it’s paper because on the reels you see a white or light grey - that’s the paper. In my other videos you would see acetate or other plastic backed which appears brown or black.

The super early formulation of tape might be part of the fidelity problem, but I think mostly Reynolds had not worked out the kinks on how to get a radio broadcast cleanly onto tape. It was clearly recorded too loud. By the time the rest of the recordings I’ve already put online were captured in 1949, 1950 and beyond - he really had a great system and the quality of those is mostly stellar. But what do you think of this recording?

The program for the performance:
https://archives.nyphil.org/index.php/artifact/9ae06c3f-2c18-4c04-9b65-617811d7ec20-0.1/fullview#page/1/mode/2up

Technical info:
Unknown Scotch, probably 100A
7” Reel
7 1/2 IPS

00:00 - Allegro moderato
10:57 - Andante con moto

Title: Novaes, Szell Beethoven Piano Concerto No. 4 NY Philharmonic 1952
Description:
George Szell conducts the NY Philharmonic in performance of Beethoven’s Piano Concerto No. 4 in G major, Op. 58, on December 21st, 1952. Brazilian pianist Guiomar Novaes is the featured soloist. 

The program for the performance:
https://archives.nyphil.org/index.php/artifact/ee0a7a98-c8b6-40df-9b9a-03c8222fb61a-0.1

This same recording is also on YouTube on a different channel that sounds about the same - but mine has Jim Fassett’s golden voice introducing (and wrapping up) the piece so in my mind it’s even better :) 

Technical Info:
Scotch 190
7” reel
7 1/2 IPS
Unfortunately this was recorded quite loud - which means the biggest loudest parts of the piece are a bit distorted. Unfortunately I couldn't fix this. On the other hand, you can very clearly hear the softer piano parts with not much extra noise. 
 
00:15 - Allegro moderato
16:57 - Andante con moto
21:45 - Rondo vivace

Title: Piano Concerto (1961), John Browning, pianist; George Szell with Cleveland Orchestra
RICHARD STRAUSS - "Don Quixote" Op.35 ~ Pierre Fournier, Concertgebouworkest, George Szell
Sensational Szell! Tchaikovsky’s 4th NY Philharmonic 1951
Description:
George Szell conducts the NY Philharmonic in performance of Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky’s Symphony No 4 in F minor, Op. 36 on December 30th, 1951. 

Honestly this has got to be one of the best sounding and most exciting recordings from my archive. I was so thrilled to discover this. Every one of Szell’s guest conducting appearances with the NY Philharmonic were special, but in this one is just so epic - the brass practically leap out of your speakers. It was recorded very “hot” (you can see the VU meter well into the red in the loud parts) but not hot enough for distortion. This was recorded from a direct line at WCCO (CBS broadcast partner station) so the fidelity is really great. 

It’s not perfect however! The reel had to be turned over about 6 minutes into the first movement - I tried to join them up as seamlessly as possible but there is still a tiny glitch. There is also sadly a bit over a minute missing from the start of the second movement. Other than those two small things we have a complete recording. 

I almost didn’t post this - when I first heard the reel back in June of 2024 it was broken up over two sides of the reel and I heard the missing part of the second movement and actually stopped the tape thinking too much was lost. But reviewing my notes I pulled it back out and figured it was worth a re-listen and reconstruction and I’m so glad I did. Do you agree this recording sounds incredible? Comment below!

The program from the performance:
https://archives.nyphil.org/index.php/artifact/5eef3b04-9e8d-49b3-b452-c34c7b403a9d-0.1?search-type=singleFilter&search-text=*&search-dates-from=12%2F30%2F1951&search-dates-to=12%2F30%2F1951

This video is from the same night:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q6zbDr5y1HQ

Technical Info:
Unknown Scotch tape type probably 111
7” reel
7 1/2 IPS
There were a few radio or machine noise artifacts that were very noticeable in quieter sections.  I went in and did some surgical edits in Izotope’s RX 11 Advanced to remove those noises. Thankfully most of it was sine waves at a fairly predictable frequency so it was easy to remove over the whole piece. 

00:07 - Andante sostenuto – Moderato con anima
17:07 - Andantino in modo di canzona
24:43 - Scherzo. Allegro
30:05 - Finale. Allegro con fuoco

Title: Szell NY Philharmonic Brahms 3rd Symphony 1952
Description:
George Szell conducts the NY Philharmonic in performance of Johannes Brahms Symphony No. 3 in F major, Op. 90, on December 21st, 1952. 

I’m pretty sure a recording of this performance doesn’t exist anywhere else - does anyone know of any other recordings? 

This was recorded quite loud (you can see the VU meter pegged into the red in the video) - which means the biggest parts of the piece are slightly distorted but I don’t think it takes away from the majesty of this performance. What do you think? 

The program for the performance:
https://archives.nyphil.org/index.php/artifact/ee0a7a98-c8b6-40df-9b9a-03c8222fb61a-0.1

Technical Info:
Scotch 190
7” reel
7 1/2 IPS

00:08 - Allegro con brio
10:14 - Andante
18:24 - Poco Allegretto
24:08 - Allegro
